loans.name: Nhip

texts.en:
Nhip is 60 years old. She is married and has 5 children, all of whom are already married. She is engaged in an agricultural business to earn a livelihood, earning an income approximately $1.00 per day.  Her husband is a worker dedicated to animal husbandry, primarily cattle.  He buys and sells at the local commercial markets. 

Nhip requires this loan to support her husband’s business and increase the number of cattle. Her goal is to increase their income and to pursue a better standard of living.

loans.use: buy more cattle

loans.name: Sokhorn

texts.en: Sokhorn, 39, is married, resides with her husband and six children in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. She is a housewife. Her husband is a palm fruit and palm juice vendor. Two of her children are employed as garment workers. Sokhorn requests a loan of USD 700 to run a new business of selling groceries at home. Currently, she haven't had grocery store yet. She will start her new business of selling grocery after she gets this loan. By doing so, she can generate more income to support her family. In the future, she would like to build a concrete grocery store, a toilet, and a kitchen, and support her children to study higher, especially English language.

loans.use: to purchase groceries to sell from home

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is 41 years old, married to Virginia, and they are blessed with one child. He has been in the farming business for the past three years with a  monthly income of Kes 5,000 which he uses to support his family.

He is applying for his first loan with KADET ltd of Kes 10,000 after being introduced by a KADET staff member. He will use the loan to buy seedlings and fertilizer for his farm. With the anticipated profit from the business he will educate his children. 

His hopes and dreams are to venture into pig rearing.

loans.use: To buy seedlings and fertilizer for his farm.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok is 71 years old. She is widowed and resides with two children in Kandal Province, Cambodia. She has been involved in growing agricultural crops for more than twenty years, earning approximately $5 daily. Her daughter is a garment worker who earns about $3 each day.

In order to improve her family’s finances, Sok is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase vegetables and butcher to resell at the market. By doing so, she would earn additional income to support the family. In the future, she would like to run hair salon for her daughter and build fence around her house.

loans.use: to purchase vegetables and butcher to resell in at the market

loans.name: Laurence

texts.en:
Laurence aged 45 years. She is married with 4 children aged between 13 and 21 years. They all go to school. She is a farmer and she has been growing maize for the past 6 years. Also her husband is a farmer. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to increase her welfare.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: A. sells cooked food to the community and other neighbors. A. has improved her sales through the TEACH lending program she participated in. She now keeps simple records of her business. She has considerably improved her sales through the TEACH lessons taught. If she is provided with a loan of $700 from KIVA she will greatly increase her profitability level.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Juana Elva

texts.en:
For the past 24 years, Juana has been making handcrafts. It is her talent for this type of work that has helped her stay in this business for so long. She is woman who is not afraid of challenges and who is completely dedicated to her job. Juana’s income is the only support she has for her young son and her mother, who lives with her. The demand for Juana’s products is increasing and she cannot cover the cost of the materials she uses in her work. This is why she needs a $200 loan.

Juana Elva needs your support to continue working. She is confident that her family and business will succeed. She plans to return the loan within 3 to 6 months. Juana and her family need your support and are sincerely grateful for your help.

Translated from Spanish by Isabel Tan, a Kiva volunteer.

Desde hace 24 años Juana se dedica a la fabricación de manualidades, su habilidad para la elaboración de este tipo de trabajo la han ayudado a permanecer por tanto tiempo en este negocio. Ella es una mujer emprendedora que se dedica por completo a su trabajo, además, el ingreso que obtiene representa el único sustento para su pequeño hijo y para su madre que vive con ella. La demanda por sus productos se ha incrementado y no puede cubrir el costo de los materiales que utiliza para elaborar sus manualidades, por lo que necesita de un préstamo de $200 dólares que utilizará con este fin.

Juana Elva necesita de tu apoyo para poder hacer su trabajo. Ella confía en que podrá sacar adelante a su familia y su negocio, por lo que planea devolver el crédito en un lapso de 3 a 6 meses. Juana y su familia necesitan de tu apoyo y agradecen sinceramente tu ayuda.

loans.use: Compra de insumos

loans.name: Nataliya

texts.en:
Nataliya is a dedicated business owner who sells women’s lingerie and socks from her little kiosk located at a busy crosswalk at the market in Kharkiv, Ukraine. In business for two years, she typically makes about $10-$15 per day. Her business is the primary source of income for her and her husband, Teodoziy. He also works but does not make as much. They have two children, a son who is 26 and a daughter who is 21 and is finishing college.

Owning her own business is a dream come true for Nataliya. She enjoys the interaction with her customers and the ability to see the fruits of her work. Eventually, she would like to open another kiosk and be able to hire someone to work for her.

Nataliya has requested a loan for $750 to help her purchase some new inventory and keep her kiosk well stocked. She has maintained an excellent credit record with Nadiya Ukraine. We are glad for this opportunity to further assist Nataliya’s business and help improve her family’s well-being.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Mahe

texts.en:
This is a group loan to be shared by the women of the association, led by. In their loan application, the group described their business as follows:

“The Takku Ligueye group has the following goals: to improve the living conditions of its members, to reactivate our business activities which were abandoned due to lack of financial means, to increase women's earnings, and to participate in the development of the local community.

The group plans the following business activities:

Retail trading: This consists of buying fish in Foundiougne [a nearby village] from the fishermen and resell them in Fatick [the town where Ndiaye Ndiaye is located] and the surrounding areas.

Sewing: The group will buy cloth and sew it [i.e. producing traditional clothing] before selling it in the local area.”

Background

Senegal is one of the world’s poorest countries, yet its solid democratic tradition and highly developed associational life distinguish it from other countries in its income group. Especially remarkable are Senegal’s networks of rotating savings and credit associations, known as tontines. Commonly organized by groups of twenty to thirty housewives who live in the same village, the tontines provide poor women throughout the country with small loans to finance modest income-generating activities. Repayment rates within these associations are excellent, because they are based on local reputation and personal trust between the members. However, their financial resources are limited to the contributions of their members, frequently subsistence farmers with very little disposable income. This has prevented the traditional tontines from meeting the demand for rural microenterprise loans and restricted their impact on the economic development of their communities. The SEM Fund works to bridge this gap by linking traditional village credit associations with outside sources of finance.

Original French business description:

«Le GIE Takku liguéye s’est fixé entre autre objectif : d’améliorer les conditions de vie de ces membres, ravivées les activités délaissées faute de moyens, augmenter le revenu des femme, et participer au développement de la localité.

Le groupement se propose des activités suivantes :

1Petit commerce : il s’agit de l’achat de poisson à foundiougne auprès des pêcheurs et venir revendre à Fatick dans la commune et dans les localités environnantes.

La couture : le groupement achètera des tissus et les coudras avant de les vendre dans la localité.»

loans.use: Purchase of fish, containers and ice for marketing of fresh fish; purchase of cloth for traditional clothing production

loans.name: Irina

texts.en: Irina has requested a loan to help purchase new inventory and increase the variety of items she has available for her little candy sales business. Irina’s business is in a great location at a market store near the bus station in Melitopol. It is convenient for customers and receives a good amount passing traffic. Irina started her business twelve years ago. She currently has about $5000 worth of inventory on hand and makes around $1400 per month in sales. This short term loan of $500 will give her extra working capital so that she can continue to develop her business and earn a good income.

loans.use: Purchase new inventory

loans.name: Oon

texts.en: Oon is 45 years old and married. She produces and sells flavored ice sticks at her house and and also consigns them  at small shops. She also sells other cooked items--fried snacks and rice in banana leaves--and earns $15 per day. She would like a loan of $100 (IDR 900,000) to expand her business by selling a wider variety of flavored ice sticks, flavored milk, and other snacks. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her inventory of food items for sale

loans.name: Essi

texts.fr:
Essi B. is married and the mother of 2 children, She installed her stall close to the bus station. She provides over 50% of the household expenses with the profit from her business. Mrs. Essi has been practicing this activity for over 5 years. She stocks up in the surrounding villages and comes back to sell them in town.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva volunteer.

Essi B. est mariée et mère de 2 enfants. Elle a installé sa baraque tout près de la gare routière. Elle participe à plus de 50% aux charges de la famille avec les bénéfices réalisés sur ces activités. Madame Essi exerce ce métier plus de 5 ans. Elle s'approvienne dans les villages environnants et revient les livrer en ville.

loans.use: To buy 5 bags of avocados, 10 baskets of bananas, 15 bags of oranges

loans.name: Yat

texts.en:
Mrs. Yat T. (age 47) is a widow with six sons. Her husband died ten years ago. Two of her sons are truck drivers and the other four are studying in the local school. Yat and her family live along National Road number one south of Phnom Penh. She has been in the business of selling bananas and flowers since 1979. She buys them from farms in her village for reselling at a market in Phnom Penh.

She is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time in the amount of $1000. She will use this loan in addition to her money for buying a truck for her son to carry construction materials and some for repairing her house.

loans.use: To buy a truck for her son to deliver construction materials and repair her house.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en: Halima H. is 30 years old and a married mother of 3. She operates a food stall in the local market and plans to use her Kiva loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To develop her business

loans.name: Katwe A(Iv) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Florence K.. She is currently in the business of selling mobile phone accessories and is requesting a loan to purchase more chargers and housings devices. Florence is 39 years old and is married. Her husband is a retired teacher. She has 5 children ranging from age 5.5 to 23 and her children go to school. Each week, Florence makes approximately UGX 100000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to invest in her business. Florence has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 100000 in order to buy a counter and more phones and the loan was paid back on time.

Florence is joined in her small group by Robinah M., Juliet W., Betty N., and Mariam N.. Robinah M. has a business in charcoal sales and wants to expand to bulk selling. Juliet W. is currently operating a grocery store business and wants a loan to purchase more groceries. Betty N. operates a beauty salon business and wants to stock more hair oils and braids. Mariam N. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to add more capital.

loans.use: To add more stock to shop

loans.name: Phoung

texts.en:
Mrs. Phoung S. was born in 1946 and she is married with Mr. Morn Yong who is a farmer. Mrs. Phoung S. is also a farmer in Kaoh Prak Village in Kandal Province and the mother of four children, two of whom are working in garment factory while the others are enrolled in school.

Last year, she faced a problem with floods which made her crop decline so she could generate only a very small income. At the same time her family also got sick; her husband had a stomachache and heart disease and they spent around $100 each time on treatment. However, the family now is in good health and they can work.

Mrs. Phoung S.’s field is dry and not fertile any longer, thus she would like to apply for a loan to buy a pump. The rest she would use to purchase fertilizer to support the field. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a pump and fertilizer.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Mrs. Elizabeth I. is 55 years old. She lives in Benin City, Nigeria. She is married with 5 children, and she sells provisions and drinks, which she learned from her mother and started 2000. She is requesting a loan of $1,200 to enable her buy more provisions and drinks for sales, to improve in her business. She has been a LAPO client for 6 years as a dedicated client.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and drinks for sale

loans.name: Allahveran

texts.en: Allahveran was born in 1955. He is married and has 4 children. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from an Armenian-occupied Fuzuli town in Azerbaijan. He is now settled in the Fuzuli region. He has been in the dairy business for 10 years. He needs a loan of $975 to buy a cow to improve his dairy business.

loans.use: Buy a cow

loans.name: Balikyewunya Women's Group

texts.en:
Mariam Nakazzi has been the chairperson of Balikyewunya women's group in Gayaza for six and a half years. She is single with six children and she cares for her sister who is in a tailoring school in Gayaza. Of her children, two are out of school and managing their own families while four are studying.

Mariam's business is selling used clothing including bed sheets, curtains and nets. She has done this for 15 years. She transacts her business by moving from one busy location to another to daily markets around her home area. She buys her stock in bales from Kampala once every week and business is good. People like secondhand clothes because they are unique and long lasting unlike new clothes. From one bale, on average Mariam makes a profit of $50 and sometimes more depending on the quality of the products. Mariam intends to use the loan to buy more bed sheets, curtains and nets for sale. Her dream is to one day open up an outlet in the trading centre so that she can sell from one place while she hires someone else to do the walking around with other stock. She believes this will increase her income, hence more profits.

Mariam will share this loan with the other group members.

loans.use: To buy more bed sheets, curtains and nets for sale.

loans.name: Akossiwavi

texts.fr:
Ms. Akossiwavi A. was born in Lomé on February 1st, 1970. She's single and has one child to support. She sells coolers and plastic trays at the Agoè Assiyéyé market, one of Lomé's local markets. Additionally, she also sells staple products in her home shop. She would like to resupply her stock and seeks this first loan to purchase 100 trays and 100 coolers.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer.

Demoiselle A. Akossiwavi est née le 1er février 1970 à Lomé. Elle est célibataire avec un enfant en charge. Elle exerce le commerce de glacières et de plats en plastique dans le marché d’Agoè Assiyéyé l’un des marchés locaux de Lomé. En plus de cette activité elle vend quelques produits de premières nécessités dans son magasin à la maison. Elle veut reconstituer son stock et sollicite ce premier crédit pour acheter 100 plats et 100 glacières.

loans.use: To purchase plastic trays and coolers

loans.name: Sang

texts.en: Sang S. L., 42, lives in Siem Reap with her husband, Doeun Samuth, and their four children. She sells a variety of grocery products out of her home, making US$10 per day of income, while her husband is a tuk-tuk driver typically making US$5 per day. One of their sons operates his own motortaxi service, as well, and can provide US$4 per day for the family. Sang S. L. has asked CREDIT for a loan of US$500 to purchase another motorbike for the family's transportation needs. Any leftover money after the purchase of the motortaxi will be used to expand the grocery inventory and help to improve her business.

loans.use: Purchase motorbike for family commute; Increase grocery store inventory

loans.name: Shu

texts.en:
Shu M. B. is married to Wanchia Walters; together they have six children. She is a very hard-working woman. 

M.'s husband married another woman and can no longer take responsibility for the children. In order to take care of herself and her children, M. joined GHAPE, where she learned the business and management techniques that helped her borrow and repay her first loan with ease.

M. provides her community with a variety of flowers for decoration. She will use this loan to buy seeds, a watering can and spade, polythene bags and other supplies. She has confidence in her in her business because she has been doing well for a long time and customers are always needing flowers to beautify their homes and communities.

loans.use: Buy flower tending supplies

loans.name: Dora

texts.es: Dora tiene 32 años, vive con sus padres. Cada día se dedica a la venta de prendas de vestir y calzado, el punto de exposición de sus productos es en un salón de belleza, también les vende a sus compañeras del salón. Periódicamente viaja a la ciudad de Lima para adquirir nueva mercadería, todas las mañanas  se le encuentra vendiendo sus productos en su vitrina y por las tardes en su centro de estudios, recientemente adicionó a su venta, accesorios para damas, de los cuales también obtiene las ganancias necesarias para su sustento. Dora trabaja de esta manera porque le permite solventar los gastos de sus estudios profesionales de medicina. Con el préstamo que obtenga comprará más mercadería, porque desea seguir con esta actividad independiente, y en el futuro tener una tienda de ropa, a la vez ser una buena profesional.
texts.en:
Dora is 32 years old and lives with her parents. Everyday, she sells apparel and footwear, displaying her merchandise in a beauty salon. She also sells her merchandise to her co-workers at the beauty salon. She periodically travels to the city of Lima in order to obtain new merchandise. Every morning, you can find her selling her products from a glass display case, and in the evening, she attends school. She recently added accessories for women to her inventory, and they help her earn more profits needed to support herself. Dora works this way because it allows her to pay for her studies in medicine. With this loan, she will purchase more merchandise because she wishes to continue with her business. In the future, she would like to have her own clothing boutique while at the same time become a fine professional.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise (clothing)

loans.name: Tarifa Javed Masih Group

texts.en:
Tarifa baji is a 38-year-old woman who resides in Walton in Lahore, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house where she has been living for the past 20 years. She completed her education until the 8th standard grade, but couldn’t get more education due to her father’s low income. Her husband, J. M., works in a cinema and provides tickets to the people. 

Tarifa baji makes decorative embroidered dresses on order and earns a good profit on them. She has successfully repaid her four previous loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy clothes, patterns, and colored thread to expand her decorative embroidery business. 

She is joined in her loan group by three more members. Samina baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine to sew clothes. Nasira baji wants a loan to buy chairs and tools for her barber salon. Nasreen baji wants a loan to buy lentils, cooking oil and spices for her food business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: "Baji," which means "older sister," is a term of respect for women in Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy material to make decorative embroidered dresses

loans.name: Madinah's Group

texts.en:
Madinah Z. is a member of Tumwesige Group in Mpunge. She is a hard-working lady with a retail shop that she has owned for a long time now. She is even having a hard time counting the many times she has had loans from Pearl Micro-finance but what she can never forget are the many achievements she has attained out of her association with other members by getting loans.

On top of her retail shop that has over time increased the quantity and quality of goods such as sugar, bread, and eggs that she sells, she has also been able to get 5 cows plus another plot of land in addition to where she is staying right now with her husband and children.

Madinah needs another loan to restock her shop with more goods for increased profits, the balance of which she will use to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: purchasing more goods for her shop

loans.name: Hoan

texts.en:
Hoan S., 24 years old, lives with her family in the province of Siem Reap in Cambodia. Her husband is a vegetable grower and they do not have any children. For over a year, she has been working in the rice trade business: collecting rice from farmers and re-selling it to earn profit. She currently earns average of $10 per day. 

Hoan S. believes her investment is doing well because she is gaining more regular customers. This business is S.'s main source of stable income for the family. In order to continue improving the business, S. is asking for a loan of $1200 to buy additional rice to sell in the future.

loans.use: To buy rice

loans.name: Vafa

texts.en: Vafa (her husband is pictured) is a mother of two children, a boy and a girl. She was born in 1976. Her husband has run a taxi business for five years. Now they need a loan of 950 AZN to buy spare parts for improving their business.

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia O. is fifty years old. She is married and has given birth to four children: three sons and one daughter. She says one of her children is at the Polytechnic, one is in senior high school, and the others are in junior high school. Felicia lives with the children in a rented apartment in a town called Dormaa Ahenkro in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. Dormaa is an agricultural dominated town. It is about forty-five minutes drive from Sunyani, the regional capital. Her husband lives and farms in a nearby village.

Felicia has been trading in charcoal for eight years. She procures bags of charcoal from nearby villages and sells them in her community. Felicia wants a loan to increase her working capital, so she can procure more bags of charcoal. She hopes to help her husband give their children the best education they can afford.

loans.use: Procure bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase grocery items for sale

loans.name: Tuwe Wakweli Group

texts.en:
Asha has been a clothes seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for one year. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $90. Daily she works at her business 12 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy clothes for resale. She is hoping that, through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to pay school fees for her children and save money for future use.

Asha is 36 years old, married, and has two children: ages 17 and 9. She also cares for two additional dependant. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Pili, who also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for resale

loans.name: 09 - Đông Hải Group

texts.en:
Phố N. Thị (10) is a 61 year-old female living in the town of Thanh Hoá.  Phố is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 9 Đông Hải (16.02.009).

Phố is married and has an adult son. To making a living, Phố owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising cattle for sale.  Phố has been engaged in this business for over 4 years and earns approximately 1.200.000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2008, Phố joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Phố has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1.626.900 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell. She is now requesting a new loan of 3.079.800 VND (USD 850) which again will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell. The loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Phố plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1.  N. Thị Vẹn  (44) is a 53 year-old female who is requesting a 3.079.800 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.

2.  N. Thị Hiếu (76) is a 37 year-old female who is requesting a 2.442.600 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.

3.  N. Thị Tú (117) is a 40 year-old female who is requesting a 3.079.800 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.

4.  B. Thị Thấu (17) is a 59 year-old female who is requesting a 3.079.800 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.




About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.




*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Phố N. Thị (10) là 61 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoá.  Phố là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 09-Đông Hải (16.02.009).

Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gia súc để bán.  Phố thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 4 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Phố kiếm được khoảng 1.200.000 VND.  Vào 2008, Phố đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Phố đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 1.626.900 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 3.079.800 VND.

Khoản vay sẽ là 3nd khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:

1.  N. Thị Vẹn  (44) là 53 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3.079.800 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.

2.  N. Thị Hiếu (76) là 37 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 2.442.600 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.

3.  N. Thị Tú (117) là 40 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3.079.800 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.

4.  B. Thị Thấu (17) là 59 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3.079.800 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.

Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell.

loans.name: Noukeïssa

texts.fr:
Née le 17 Janvier 1978 à Kayes, célibataire et mère de 2 enfants,  Noukeïssa Sidibé  réside avec sa sœur  et ses enfants à Sanoubougou I, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu la chance d’avancer à l’école pour des raisons sociales, elle s’initia très tôt aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment l’achat-vente des draps de lit, d’habits pour enfants, de pagnes wax, des tissus brodés, etc.  Elle est beaucoup sollicitée  de sa clientèle (composée essentiellement des femmes) pour la qualité de ses produits.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant trois  ans. Après 2 prêts solidaires (prêt du groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier (Association JEKAFO de Sanoubougou II) et deux prêts individuels, tous correctement remboursés, elle est à son troisième prêt individuel.
Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 4 douzaines de complets pour enfants, 6 complets de draps de lit, 4 complets de tissus brodés et des pièces de pagne wax.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   
Elle achète ses marchandises à Bamako et effectue ses ventes  au comptant, à crédit en détail et de façon ambulante  essentiellement  auprès des fonctionnaires des services publics et privés  de  Sikasso. 
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 90 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born on January 17, 1978 in Kayes, Ms. Noukeïssa Sidibé is unmarried and the mother of two children. She resides with her sister and children in Sanoubougou I, a working-class district of Sikasso City (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having lacked the chance to continue with her schooling due to societal reasons, she was soon introduced to income-generating work, notably buying and selling bed sheets, children's clothing, Wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth), embroidered fabrics, etc. She is in high demand by her customers (composed essentially of women) for the quality of her products. Concerned about doing better in satisfying her burgeoning customer base, she decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. After two solidarity loans (group loans) in a women's association in her area (Association JEKAFO de Sanoubougou II) and two individual loans, all correctly repaid, she is now on her third individual loan. This loan will be used to buy four dozen outfits for children, six sets of bed sheets, four outfits of embroidered fabrics, and bolts of Wax pagnes. Supplies are gotten in Bamako, and sales are made at the retail level, cash or credit accepted, while going door-to-door. Her customers are composed essentially of civil servants and private company employees of Sikasso. She envisions using this loan to realize a monthly profit of 90,000 francs CFA that will be used to augment her working capital, to help cover family expenses, to make loan interest payments, and to invest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bed sheets, cloth, embroidered fabrics, and children's clothing

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario B. is 55 years old this year. She is a widow and has eight children. She has a small rice field that she has been managing on her own since the death of her husband. For 25 years, she has been tilling the field and reaping an average of 80 sacks of rice grains every harvest. The farm has helped her buy the things the family needs. This will be the same farm that she will give to her children in the future.

She is asking a loan of Php 12,000 from CEVI to purchase fertilizers and chemicals. The loan will help increase her harvest and income.

CEVI helps small business grow. CEVI provides their clients with not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and chemicals.

loans.name: Sor Erlinda Del Socorro

texts.es: Doña Sor Erlinda tiene la edad de 42 años, reside en jardines de Veracruz en la capital de Managua, tiene dos hijos los cuales están cursando sus estudios, su esposo  trabaja de comerciante. El negocio de la señora Sor Erlinda es la venta de ropa usada con este negocio lleva siete años en las ventas, ella inicio este negocio con el deseo de superación para apoyar a su esposo con los gasto de la familia con dinero propio el cual inicio con la venta de prendas, pero luego comenzó a vender ropa usada ambulante. Con este crédito quiere invertir en la compra de ropa variada nueva, para que sus clientes puedan tener las opciones de elegir a si como captar nuevos clientes. Sus planes para sus hijos es poderlos ayudar a que terminen sus estudios para que sean unos profesionales.
texts.en:
Sor Erlinda is 42, and she lives in the Veracruz gardens in the capital city, Managua. She has two children who go to school. Her husband is a storekeeper. Sor Erlinda sells used clothes. She has been doing this for seven years. She started this business with the desire to succeed and help her husband with the family expenses. She started with her own money; she sold clothes. Then she started to sell used clothing as a street vendor. With this loan she will buy various new clothes so that her customers have a selection to choose from. This way she will get new customers. Her plan is to be able to help her children finish their education so that they can become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy children's, women's, and men's clothing

loans.name: Tuychiboi

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
Туйчибой - молодой мужчина 32 лет. Женат и отец 3-х детей. Образование среднее. Занимается откормом и продажей скота. Жену зовут Бахринисо, ей 30 лет. Она нигде не работает, нянчит своих маленьких детей. А также помогает мужу по хозяйству и откармливает скот. Туйчибой пасет овец на пастбище целый день. Туйчибой кредитуется у нас с 2007 года. За это время он показал себя только с хорошей стороны. Добросовестный и честный клиент. За два года кредитования он увеличил количество своего скота. Туйчибой хочет взять займ для покупки быков.
texts.en:
Tuychiboi is a young man of 32. He is married and the father of three children. He has a secondary school education. Tuychiboi's business is fattening and selling livestock. His wife Bakhrinisso is 30 years old and stays home watching their young children. However, she also helps her husband with the business and feeds the livestock. Tuychiboi is out grazing their sheep on the pasture all day. Tuychiboi has been a conscientious and honest client since he took his first loan out from MLF "MicroInvest" in 2007. The loans he received over the last two years allowed him to increase the size of his herd. Tuychiboi is planning to use this loan to buy more cattle.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fattening and selling livestock

loans.name: Altantsetseg

texts.en:
Altantsetseg D. is a 41-year-old, married and a mother of two children. Her family lives in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She has fully repaid her first Kiva loan, which will appear on www.kiva.org in August when the repayments are posted online.

Altantsetseg is a professional tailor. She runs a sewing business out of a 10-square-meter rented room. In 2007, she started her business by buying a sewing machine and fabric that cost MNT 40,000 ($1.00 USD=1,450.00 MNT). Her business has been successful ever since and has allowed her to purchase three more sewing machines and hire two tailors. Her working capital has grown from 40,000 MNT to 1.5 million MNT. Her daily income now is around 1.0 million MNT.

Altantsetseg gets many orders due to the lack of competing businesses in her area. With her profits, her husband built a 40 sq. meter house on the plot of land that they own. Before her business flourished, she lived in a "ger" (traditional, nomadic form of tent housing) in the local ger district. One of her sons goes to elementary school, the other one is a university student. She is requesting a loan to repair and expand her house. With this loan she will purchase building material.

loans.use: To purchase building material

loans.name: Kurbon

texts.en:
M. Kurbon is an energetic man who has been a farmer for 15 years. He is happily married to a hardworking woman who always supports him. She has helped him get ahead in life and has given him 4 children. Like most other people in the zone who depend on the vegetable crop, Kurbon needs to buy agricultural supplies that will allow for the maintenance and production of his crops up to the optimum harvest time. With this purpose Kurbon applied to IMON International for a loan of 3500 Somoni to purchase agricultural supplies like seeds and fertilizer. Kurbon and his beloved family sincerely thank you for your support.   

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing the seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Santos Isidoro

texts.es: Santos Eliodoro R. L.  tiene la edad de 51 años, vive en su casa de habitación con su esposa.  Tiene 3 hijos y todos  trabajan de manera independiente.  Su actividad económica es una pulpería. Hace más de 22 años que se dedica a este negocio. Por lo que inicio ofreciendo la venta de productos básicos como arroz, azúcar, aceite y frijoles. Ya que su negocio fue una herencia de sus padres. Por lo que el principal negocio de Santos es satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes ofreciéndoles lo que ellos solicitan. Es así como recurre a Fundación León 2000 ya que por medio ella las organizaciones amigas dan el apoyo necesario y solicita el financiamiento para capital de trabajo para granos básicos, golosinas, refrescos, gaseosas, bisutería y leche en bolsa. El deseo de Santos es convertir su negocio en una distribuidora.
texts.en:
Santos Eliodoro R. L. is 51 years old and lives with his wife. He has 3 children who all work independently. His economic activity is a grocery store. He has dedicated himself to this business for more than 22 years. He started out offering basic items such as rice, sugar, cooking oil and green beans. He inherited the business from his parents. His primary goal is to satisfy the needs of his customers by offering them what they request. This is how he turned to Fundación León 2000, since it is through these friendly organizations that he can receive the support necessary and solicit financing for working capital to buy items such as snacks, refreshments, sodas, costume jewelry and milk in bags. Santos’ wish is to convert his business into a distributorship.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is 63 years old and she is married with 8 children. She sells fire woods in retail to her customers.She hopes for the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more fire woods to sell.She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more firewoods to sell

loans.name: Gleider

texts.es:
Gleider se dedica a la venta de perfumes y cosméticos como también suplementos alimenticios.
Vive en la zona de San Jorge  de la Ciudad de La Paz, en casa alquilada
El crédito será destinado para capital de trabajo (compra de perfumes, cosméticos, batidos, vitaminas y otros). Con este crédito podrá mejorar sus ingresos y condiciones de vida
Es la segunda vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, su historial la califica como cliente 1 es decir con cumplimiento bueno en el pago de su crédito.

loans.use: Compra de perfumes, cosméticos, vitaminas y otros para su negocio de venta de los mismos al por menor.

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience B. sells jewelry and clothes in Kwamikrom. Patience has received a junior high education. She is married and has three children. Patience has been selling jewelry and clothes since 2003. She helps her husband in footing the housekeeping expenses. Her loan will be used to buy more jewelry and clothes for resale. She hopes to reinvest the new profits from her business.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy more jewelry and clothes for resale.

loans.name: Los Fuerte 2 & 3 Group

texts.en:
Emilia, 24, lives near San Pedro de Macorís, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group Los Fuerte (The Strong), and her story is representative of the other borrowers in the group. 

Emilia and the other members of Los Fuerte live in Boca Chica, a small town west of San Pedro. Emilia lives with her sister and her nine-year-old son. Life in Boca Chica can be difficult; despite its proximity to San Pedro as well as the capital, Santo Domingo, Boca Chica lacks any kind of reliable electricity or running water. 

Despite these difficulties, Emilia runs a successful shop selling clothing and hair products to her neighbors and friends. The shop is set up in her home, but one day she would like to have a separate place for her business. With the loan that she is requesting - her second loan with Esperanza - she hopes to begin saving more so that she can send her son to college one day. Thank you for lending to Emilia and the Los Fuerte group!

loans.use: purchasing hair products and more clothing

loans.name: Nicida

texts.es:
La señora Nicida, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Manuela Ramos”, Distrito D. Zapatero, Provincia D. Lamas, Departamento D. San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 52 años, es madre D. 05 hijos, 01 que aun depenD. D. ella.

Nicida, lleva 04 años dedicándose a la confección D. ropas interiores y poco a poco fue generando sus propios ingresos y ahorrando su dinero, queriendo así implementar su propio taller y como tenia habilidad  para la costura, no dudo en hacerlo y con el apoyo del Movimiento Manuela Ramos, logro implementarlo. 
Nos cuenta que le va muy en sus costuras, trabaja con pedidos que con anticipación sus clientes le solicitan. A quienes les  atienD.  con la amabilidad y el carisma  que le caracteriza. 

 Con este préstamo D. S/. 1,500.00, comprará telas en metros, D. diferentes especies y colores, instrumentos que utiliza como tijeras, hilos en carretes grandes y D. variados colores, agujas D. coser y D. maquina, alfileres, botones. 

Hoy en día se siente una mujer muy realizada, con más ganas D. alcanzar y hacer realidad sus demás sueños. Agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudarla a iniciar su negocio y también a muchas mujeres que  quieren crecer empresarialmente.
texts.en:
Señora Nicida belongs to the communal bank “Manuela Ramos”, in the Zapatero district of Lamas province in the San Martin region. She is married, 52 years old, and is the mother of 5 children, one of whom is still a dependent. Nicida has maD. undergarments for 4 years, and little by little she was generating her own income and saving her money, wanting to have her own workshop. With her skills in sewing she had no doubt that she could do it, and with the support of the Movimiento Manuela Ramos organization she was able to accomplish this. She tells us that it is going very well; she works on orders that her customers place in advance. She attends to them with characteristic friendliness and charisma. With this loan of 1,500 soles nuevos she will buy meters of fabric in different types and colors, tools such as scissors, thread on large spools in a variety of colors, needles for hand and machine sewing, pins and buttons. Today she feels like a very accomplished woman, with a desire to continue to reach for her goals and make her other dreams a reality. She is grateful to the Movimiento Manuela Ramos organization for helping her start her business, and also for helping many women who want to grow as entrepreneurs.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy dressmaking supplies

loans.name: Sotero

texts.es:
El señor Sotero B. está muy agradecido por su cooperación en el anterior crédito el cual le pudo construir la recamara de su hijo. 
Le está haciendo falta un pequeño cuarto que será el baño ya que el que tiene actual mente esta en malos condiciones y tiene miedo que les pueda pasar algo a su familia. 
Es por eso que está solicitando nueva mente su cooperación para este crédito. Planea pagarlo con los ingresos que obtiene de su trabaja en una compañía de trasportes en el departamento de cargas y descargas, y en las tardes se dedica a vender Hot Dogs con estas ganancias cubrirá los gastos familiares.
texts.en:
Sotero B. is very grateful for your cooperation with the previous loan, which he used to build a bedroom for his son. He needs a small room to be the bathroom. The one he currently has is in bad condition, and he is afraid that something could happen to his family. That is why he is asking again for your cooperation with a new loan. He plans to pay it with the income he gets from his work in the loading and unloading department of a transportation company. In the afternoons he sells hot dogs. These earnings will cover the family expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build a bathroom

loans.name: Tamara

texts.en: Tamara A. was born in 1961 in Ijevan. She is married and has a 28-year-old son. Tamara works at the Armenian post office as a postman. She also has her own business trading fruits and vegetables in Ijevan market. Tamara’s son helps her in this business. Thanks to this business, they can provide their family’s needs. She needs a 350.000-AMD loan to buy citrus for her business. With the future income, she plans to buy furniture for her house.

loans.use: To buy citrus to sell

loans.name: Liza

texts.en: Liza U. is from the village of Sagay, Camiguin Province. She is 37 years old. Liza is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Liza owns and operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing repair services for all types of vehicles in the local community. Liza has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Liza joined HSPFI, a Kiva partner, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Liza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. Liza is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Liza from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Antonia

texts.es:
Antonia, de 36 años, es una mujer muy trabajadora y luchadora, vive en su casa propia junto a su esposo William, de 37 años, y lo que más desea es sobresalir en la vida.
La elaboración de ladrillos es la actividad a la que se dedica, su horno está ubicado en las afueras de la ciudad de Juliaca. Ella se levanta muy temprano, y junto a su esposo comienzan con el amasado y moldeado del barro, para luego dejarlo secar por 10 días y meterlo al horno.
Por otro lado, lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es vender sus ladrillos, ya que siente que su trabajo es recompensado. Lleva 10 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es trabajar sin importar el clima, puesto que muchas veces el sol hace que el trabajo sea más pesado o la lluvia impide que los ladrillos se moldeen correctamente, aun así ella continua trabajando duro para mejorar su calidad de vida. 
Para más adelante, desea implementar una bodega en su casa, ya que actualmente hay muy pocas por su barrio.

Este es el tercer préstamo al que accede con MFP y al igual como hizo con sus anteriores préstamos, desea pagarlo a tiempo y sin dificultades. En su banco comunal es muy respetada, ya que es la socia más activa y comprometida. Con los tres mil nuevos soles solicitados comprará nuevos moldes para ladrillos de techo, ya que es lo que más le solicitan.
texts.en:
Antonia is 36 years old and a hardworking, determined woman. She lives in her own house with her husband William, who is 37. They both wish to succeed in life.

Antonia engages in the manufacture of bricks. Her oven is located on the outskirts of the city of Juliaca. Together with her husband, she wakes up early in the morning to begin kneading and molding the clay before letting it dry for ten days prior to baking in the oven. What she enjoys most about her job is selling the bricks, which is the point in which she feels rewarded for her work. Antonio has been in this business for ten years and believes the most difficult part is dealing with the weather. Many times while working in the sun, the work becomes more difficult. When it rains, she is not able to mold the bricks correctly. Nevertheless, she continues to work hard in order to improve her quality of life. In the future, she would like to open a grocery store in her house because there are few in her neighborhood.

This is the third loan that she has accessed from MFP. Just like her previous loans, Antonia wants to make her payments on time and with little difficulty. She is highly respected by her Communal Bank because she is one of the most active and committed members. With her loan of 3000 soles, she plans to buy new molds for making roofing bricks since these are the type that are most requested.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase molds for making bricks

loans.name: Folorunsho

texts.en:
Folorunsho lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 33 years old, married, and blessed with two children. Folorunsho is a trader who sells drinks, sachet water and ice blocks in small quantities to her customers. Her business is very lucrative, especially in the dry season. In the future, she hopes to have a mini depot for her drinks business.
Folorunsho is requesting a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more drinks to sell. This will enable her to meet high customer demand. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita B. is from the village of Mahayahay in Initao, Misamis Oriental. She is 52 years old. Rosita is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Rosita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) store where she sells a variety of different products in the local community. Rosita has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Rosita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosita is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase new items to sell. This will be Rosita's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nadina

texts.en: Nadina M. is from the village of Magsaysay, Gingoog city. She is 29 years old, is married, and has five school-aged children. Nadina owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Nadina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. Nadina plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Adela Antonia

texts.es: La Sra. Adela B. es originaria del caserío San Ramón del municipio de El Sauce. Su negocio consiste en la venta de cuajada y leche los cuales los elabora en su casa de habitación para luego venderlos en la terminal de buses, tiene ocho años de experiencia en este oficio. Trabaja con ceprodel desde hace dos años donde le han otorgado cuatro créditos para invertirlos en su negocio el que le  ha permitido mantener a su familia y salir adelante cada día.
texts.en:
Adela B. is from the San Ramón rural community in the El Sauce municipality. Her business is selling curd and milk. She makes them at home, and she later sells them at the bus terminal. She has been doing this for eight years. She has worked with Ceprodel for two years. She has had four loans, which she invested in her business. This has allowed her to support her family and to get ahead each day.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy soft drinks, rice, sugar, sweets, and milk

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
B. Moses has, for over twenty-one years, been selling maize as his source of income. His business prospers on the basis that foods prepared with maize flour are in high favor with many Ugandans. In the photo, Moses is the one wearing the jacket.

In Wakitaka, this 35-year-old married man is referred to as an early riser: one who rises with the lark. He is a stickler for hard work and, as such, his three children are all basking in the glow of his enterprising nature. His business brings him monthly profits of 120,000 shillings.

Moses is looking at a scenario where his business will expand with aplomb. The only way he sees this materializing is when he obtains a loan. With it he wants to buy more maize.

loans.use: To buy more maize for his business

loans.name: Agustina

texts.en:
Agustina A. is a 57-year-old married woman who lives in Hda. San Ramon, Poblacion, Bayawan City, Negros Oriental. Agustina has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon for eight years now and earns a living by running a food vending businsess. She is purchasing a solar lantern with a 3,100 Philippine peso loan from NWTF to extend her productive hours and at the same time cut fuel costs and save money in the long run.

Agustina is shown in the accompanying photo with the solar lantern that she just bought from the NWTF-Project Dungganon branch in Bayawan City, Negros Oriental.

About NWTF’s Green Loan Products
Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation believes that the key to poverty alleviation for the poorest is to provide services beyond just credit. To that end, NWTF offers green energy products designed to save money for its clients. In a partnership with SunTransfer and Arc Finance, NWTF distributes solar-powered lanterns that also function as charging stations for mobile phones. These families normally use kerosene lamps to light their homes. The solar lantern offers a free, environmentally friendly, renewable source of energy that allows them to reduce their monthly fuel costs.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem  that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To purchase a solar lantern

loans.name: Able God #1 Group

texts.en:
Morris T. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Able God #1.  He is 42 years old, married and has four children who range from 8 to 17 years old.  He was only able to attend school to 11th grade due to poverty.


For 3 years, Morris has been selling shoes and plastic bags at the Chicken Soup Market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia.  He sells in a friendly manner which keeps his customers coming back.  
He plans to use his LRD 8,000 portion of this LRD 40,000 group loan to buy more plastic bags and shoes. His goal is to grow his business and to continue to support his children so that they can have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Morris is the one holding the sign.

loans.use: To buy more plastic bags and shoes.

loans.name: Véronique

texts.fr: Née en 1980 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, N. Véronique est mariée à AGOUNLA Théophile, un gendarme à la retraite. Le couple a trois enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. Il y a environs sept ans que Véronique s'est installée à Ekpè dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple se partage ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Véronique n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Véronique est une revendeuse ambulante de sachets depuis cinq ans environs. Véronique s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Benin. C’est la première fois que Véronique sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un prêt, afin de renforcer son capital ; ce qui lui permettra de mieux faire face aux besoinx de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Born in 1980 in Cotonou, economic capital of Bénin, N. Véronique is married to AGOUNLA Théophile, a retired policeman. The couple has three children, some of whom are enrolled in school. Véronique settled in Ekpè in the township of Sèmè-Podji, about seven years ago, with her children and her husband. The couple share in supporting their family. Véronique never went to school. She has been walking around the town selling bags for about five years. She buys her supplies in Dantokpa, international market of Benin. This is the first time that Véronique is requesting a loan from ALIDé, in order to grow her working capital. This will allow her to better cater for the needs of her clientele.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of bags for resale

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 60-year old married woman from Lebanon, living with her husband and two children. Twenty years ago she started working in a pastry store and at the age of 58 she took the risk and started her own business. Her husband purchased a store for her to sell her home-made pastries.
She is now requesting a loan of $1,000  to purchase inventory for her shop.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for her pastry shop

loans.name: Ivy

texts.en:
Ivy F. is from Camiguin   Province. She is 32 years old. Ivy is widowed and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Ivy owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products  including fish and shrimp in the local community. Ivy has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Ivy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ivy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase new items to expand product offering. Ivy is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Ivy from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Chhourn

texts.en:
Chhourn T., 45, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known as the most favorite tourist place in the country. T. sells fish, earning a gross income of USD 38 per day. Her husband is a farmer and earns an income of USD 1 per day.

T. is requesting a loan of USD 200 to purchase more fish to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more fish to resell.

loans.name: Bekkul

texts.en:
Bekkul A. was born into a family of farm workers, where cattle-breeding was passed on from one generation to another. From early childhood, he helped his parents in farming and animal breeding. After graduating from secondary school and serving in the army, he returned home and got a job at a local farm.

Later, after marrying and becoming a father of three children, Bekkul decided to start his own business in cattle breeding. Using his starting capital of 3,000 Kyrgyz Soms, he bought one milk cow and, owing to a persistent and hardworking personality, managed to multiply his investments. Presently, his farm has 3 milk cows, 20 sheep and 2 bulls. Last year, Bekkul applied for a loan to buy cattle and repaid it without any delays.

Bekkul plans to use this loan of 65,000 Kyrgyz Soms to increase his number of cattle for fattening and reselling, and in the future he plans to buy a car for his elder son and hold his wedding.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Marta Irene

texts.es:
La señora O. López es Originaria de la comarca el Tololar , es de oficio Maestra de primaria en la misma comarca , su núcleo familiar está compuesto por dos personas menores de edad, este cliente posee una pequeña vivienda que poco a poco ha ido mejorando con esfuerzos propios, este es el octavo financiamiento
Que se le ha otorgado de parte de ceprodel  para gastos personales y gastos médicos.
texts.en:
Ms. O. López is a native of the Tololar district. She is an elementary school teacher by profession, in the same district. Her family unit includes two minor children. The borrower owns a small home which she has gradually been improving through her own efforts. This is her eighth loan, which has been granted by CEPRODEL for personal and medical expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Paying medical expenses

loans.name: Tirigot Ole Kerenge

texts.en:
Tirigot Ole Kerenge N. is 24 years old. He is a farmer and supports four people in his family. His spouse is Nayengiyengunye and they have two children who are eight and two years old. Nayengiyengunye is a housewife and helps Tirigot in his farming activity.

Tirigot does wheat farming, which he has been doing for the last five years. This will be his second loan and he plans to spend it to prepare his five-acre farm for planting wheat. He is planning to use the anticipated profit from his farming to expand his farming activity by hiring a bigger piece of land to increase his wheat production. His hope and dream is to become a large-scale farmer owning a bigger piece of land and be financially stable to support his family. He is a hard-working man and determined to achieve his objective.

loans.use: To prepare his land for planting wheat.

loans.name: La Victoire Group

texts.fr: Faida Joséphine  est  présidente  groupe la victoire, âgée de 48 ans, mariée, mère de 8 enfants, son mari est  chômeur. Son fils ainé a 26 ans et le cadet a 8 ans et tous étudient.  Il y a 26 ans qu’elle exerce le petit commerce de vente de la bière  Primus et Fanta. Elle a commence avec ses fonds propre reçu de son père environ 50$. Elle expose ses marchandises à son  domicile et parfois sur la rue publique. Ce crédit va lui permettre d’augmenter  son chiffre d’affaire en achetant  une parcelle de 1100$ en y associant ses épargnes  cumulatives de cycle. Le grand obstacle est  qu’elle vend en monnaie nationale (franc congolais). Cependant cette monnaie congolaise n’est pas stable, elle subit de plus à plus l’inflation, ce qui entraine de perte de change avec la devise (les dollars), comme tous les congolais craignent le franc congolais, pour garder leurs économies en dollars. Elle souhaite voir  ses enfants finir les études et doubler ses caisses de Primus et Fanta  de 40 à 70 caisses. La cliente Faida Joséphine remercie  Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres citoyens exclus de banque classique.  Il sied de signaler que ce groupe la victoire est composé de 13 membres.
texts.en:
Faida Joséphine is the president of the La Victoire group, is 48 years old and a married mother of eight whose husband is unemployed. Her eldest son is 26 and the youngest is 8 years old; all her children are in education. She began selling Primus beer and Fanta 26 years ago. She began the business with funds that she received from her father, around 50$. She showcases her wares from her home and sometimes on the road. This loan will enable her to boost her revenues by purchasing a 1100$ plot of land through cumulative loans. The main obstacle is that she sells her goods in local currency (Congolese franc). However this currency is not stable and is subject to high inflation and often loses value against the dollar; all Congolese merchants fear the franc and keep their transactions in dollars. She would like to see her children finish school and double her stock of Primus and Fanta from 40 to 70 cases. Faida Joséphine would like to thank Hekima for its actions that help poor citizens who are excluded from the mainstream banking system. The La Victoire group is made up of thirteen members.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: A 1100$ plot of land

loans.name: Gevorg

texts.en: Gevorg M. is married with 2 children. The happy family lives with Gevorg’s pensioner parents. Gevorg has been in the car spare parts business since 2008. He has longstanding and well-developed customer relations. Being a good and trustworthy businessman, Gevorg offers his clients competitive deals. With the business income, Gevorg takes care of his whole family. Gevorg would like to purchase spare parts to meet his clients’ needs and extend the business.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts.

loans.name: Joseph Kuria

texts.en:
Joseph Kuria M. is 49 years old, married to Racheal Nyambura and has four children. He has been farming in Olkalou for the last thirteen years.

Joseph was introduced to KADET by his friend. This will be his third loan. He paid all his previous loans well and in good time. He plans to use this loan to buy a dairy cow and start producing milk to sell.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Chum

texts.en:
Mrs. Chum R. is a vegetable seller who is 55 and is a married mother caring for four children, three of whom are single while the remaining one is married. All of them are employed in various jobs.

 Mrs. Chum R. has been selling vegetables for years in the busy market, and her business is running well because she sells her items at a reasonable cost to all customers. Her husband is a local farmer in the province of Kompong Tom. Because she has been occupied with her business, Mrs. Chum R. hasn't plowed her farmland yet. To solve this problem, Mrs. Chum R. is applying for a loan to hire a machine to plow the farmland. With the rest of the loan she will buy some vegetables to sell.

loans.use: To hire a machine to plow farmland and  buy some vegetable to sell

loans.name: Madalena

texts.en:
Madalena C. is a Single woman who lives in Purok 4, Brgy. Tinungan, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating one business venture: a general store business.  Madalena joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 16 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Madalena has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. 

Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 5,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 17th loan, she is borrowing PHP 12,000, which she intends to buy additional stock for the general store so that she could continue to save up for future expansion of her business. Madalena C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 	

About NWTF:
 In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more inventory to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy materials to make advertising

loans.name: Juan Bautista

texts.es:
el sr. Juan F. tiene 29 años de edad, vive en la colonia santa anita de yusguare y se dedica a la venta de productos de consumo popular, tiene una pulperia en su casa de habitacion. Juan es una persona emprendedora y  dedicado a su  negocio, es padre de 2 hijos los cuales los tiene en la escuela de la comunidad. 
el y su esposa trabajan duro para sacar adelante la familia, se levanta a las 5 de la mañana para atender a su 
clientela.
el credito lo utilizara para la compra de mercaderia y asi surtir su negocio, desea tener bien surtido su negocio para navidad.

su tiempo libre lo dedica a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Mr. Juan F. is 29 years old, lives in Santa Anita de Yusguare, and dedicates his business to the sale of general consumer goods.  His store is based out of his home.  Juan is entrepreneurial and dedicated to his business.  He is the father of 2 children, both of whom go to a community school.  He and his wife work hard to give their family a better life.  Each morning he wakes up at 5am to attend to his customers.

He will use his loan to purchase merchandise and stock his business.  He hopes to have his store fully stocked by Christmas.  Juan spends his free time with his family.

loans.use: Purchase rice, sugar, butter, cooking oil, churros, refreshments, cheese, lard, chicken, coffee, milk, bread, crackers, soup, pasta, toilet paper, paper towels, batteries, candles, and matches.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn A. is from the town of Banga. She is 42 years old. Evelyn is married and has six children. To make a living, Evelyn raises crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting corn for sale. Evelyn has been engaged in farming for more than four years.

Evelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.
